description: From Middle English eddy, from Old English edēa, from ed- (“turning, back, reverse”) + ēa (“water”), equivalent to ed- +‎ ea. Ultimately from PIE *h₁é, "and, consequently," cognate with Latin "et." Related also to Danish ide (“eddy”), Swedish eda (“eddy”), Norwegian ida, ia, ea (“eddy”),  Icelandic iða (“eddy”).

entries.meaning: A current of air or water running back, or in an opposite direction to the main current.

verbs.description: eddy (third-person singular simple present eddies, present participle eddying, simple past and past participle eddied)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To form an eddy; to move in, or as if in, an eddy; to move in a circle.
examples: Eddying round and round they sink.
